JAMISON:Â  Everyone writes their modules in different module formats or syntax. Is there anything solving the problem from the other end as, â€œI, as a module author, have made this useful code. What do I do to make it so people can use it?â€ GUY:Â  Yeah, and that is a problem, because as a module author, you have to support everything because you want to get your code out as widely as possible. JAMISON:Â  Yeah. GUY:Â  [inaudible] on these different systems. JAMISON:Â  You canâ€™t count on everyone using jspm, so you just say Iâ€™ll make it in CommonJS and then whoever wants to can use Require, use whatever they want with it. GUY:Â  And it is unfortunate. So, module authors do get frustrated by this, because they have to have one version for this format, another version for this, different package to JSON and all this kind of stuff. And unfortunately, that is something that we have to go through. And itâ€™s necessary to making sure that package management can evolve properly. We need to have systems running side-by-side and let the best win, effectively. So, the way that jspm deals with that is it doesnâ€™t add a new, it has no jspm.json. It shares the package.json information and it has some metadata that can be useful in certain scenarios. And if module authors donâ€™t want to use it, thereâ€™s an override service. So for example, if thereâ€™s a repo on GitHub like bootstrap for example, and they donâ€™t want to support this jspm configuration in their package.json, we can actually override that through, thereâ€™s a repo on GitHub where jspm can override that configuration when you first install it. So, effectively making that sort of stuff possible from both sides. So, if the framework authorâ€™s frustrated with all these different systems, a user can still go and set up their own configuration and that will work for everyone using jspm. JAMISON:Â  Thatâ€™s cool. JOE:Â  Yeah, thatâ€™s really cool. So, is it at all like that scenario where the guy goes out and he looks and he sees that there are five standards, and he says, â€œThis is ridiculous. There are five different standards. I think if youâ€™re happy using AMD or youâ€™re happy using CommonJS today, keep doing that. Thereâ€™s no reason to rush into ES6. If youâ€™re already having frustrations in your workflows and youâ€™re thinking about ES6 modules, thinking about how modules can be standardized, then try these projects out. But itâ€™s very much, I think, something that will take time. And for me personally, I just got very frustrated with the fact that you had to choose AMD or CommonJS. And having made that decision, you had to live with it. And I really just wanted a system of dealing with modules that couldnâ€™t be refuted with a blog post or something like that. I spent about a year building a framework on top of AMD and AMD started to fall out of favor just as the framework was finished. And I found it incredibly frustrating that I built a lot of work on top of a system that could so easily not turn out to be used as widely as Iâ€™d hoped. I think with ES6 we have the potential for a really solid foundation. And I think thatâ€™s important in development to have solid foundations. JOE:Â  So, what are some potential pain points people might experience that would cause them to want to look at ES6 modules and by that extension, your stuff? GUY:Â  Some of the areas that we can do that might be harder in other systems are things like, well firstly, if you do come up against interrupt issues with different module systems. So, wanting to be able to just write modules in a way thatâ€™sâ€¦ wanting to have a spec-supported syntax for writing modules. So, if I can write an app and know that Iâ€™ve written all my modules as ES6, I know that that code is going to be safe in the future. I know that five years down the line, more that code will still be something thatâ€™s on solid foundations. Whereas if Iâ€™m writing code today thatâ€™s only going to be around for a few years, itâ€™s not a problem to use other formats, but with ES6 you can, if I was building a codebase that needed to last for a while, itâ€™s nice to build on ES6. And then, the other problems we can solve are things like effectively the transition into HTTP 2.0. So, moving away from bundling over time. Asset loading. So, you can actually load assets in the module pipeline. I can even load an HTML import in the module pipeline if I wanted to, or CSS is a really useful one as well. So, youâ€™ve got a CSS loading mechanism in a module system, which means that you can have modular components that are combinations of CSS template and JavaScript, which is really what we want. And then weâ€™re also working on things around conditional loading and those kinds of problems too. So, how do you conditionally load libraries depending on the environment? And because weâ€™re building those solutions on top of the ES6 module loader, weâ€™re hopefully doing it in a fairly solid way going forward. What else? I think those are probably the main reasons, yeah. CHUCK:Â  So, related to that, where do you see things going next, especially from the standpoint of managing code through modules like this? GUY:Â  Well, what Iâ€™d like to see is just it being really easy to start prototyping and building new apps. And for the workflows not to cause so much friction that the thought of including a new library becomes something painful. So, in the same way that npm has done for Node, to see that happening properly in the browser. So, if I want to build a site and just add new, little features to it, it should be an easy install process. With HTTP 2.0, whatâ€™s cool is you can actually enable requiring without needing a package manager. So, if Iâ€™m using an asset CDN, I can actually load modules directly off that asset CDN without needing to go through an install process. So, I just think thatâ€™s really nice to be able to imagine you can have this really complex app, a proper application in the browser, and it can by dynamically loading new modules very easily. And they just fall into this existing registry. So, if you want to bring in new functionality, you can have much more sophisticated apps in the browser. So for example, you could start writing ES6, transpiling that into CommonJS and using that, or there are a lot of different compilation techniques.
